newsitem.title: USA: Two White House helicopters suffer problems.
newsitem.headline: Two White House helicopters suffer problems.

text.p: Two Marine Corps CH-46E helicopters supporting the entourage of U.S. President Bill Clinton were involved in separate incidents on Friday, one rolling over and burning at a local airport and the other landing in a nearby field after a warning light went on.
There were no injuries and Clinton, on a two-day campaign trip to Florida, was not involved in either incident, defence officials said in Washington.
Marine Corps officials at the Pentagon said the incidents, which followed the crash of a presidential travel support plane last month, occurred only a short time apart but were not connected.

A C-130 Air Force cargo plane that accompanied Clinton on his vacation trip to Jackson, Wyoming, crashed on a Wyoming mountain on Aug. 17, killing all nine people aboard. Eight were crew members and one was a Secret Service agent.

One of the big twin-bladed CH-46E "Sea Knight" cargo helicopters was taxiing on a runway at Orlando Executive Airport when it rolled over and burned for unknown reasons. All the four or five crew members escaped safely, White House spokesman Mike McCurry told reporters.
That helicopter had been used on Thursday to transport members of the presidential party but not Clinton, who was elsewhere in Orlando when the incident occurred.

Marine Corps officials said a second CH-64E helicopter also landed safely in a field about 12 miles (20 km) south of Orlando after a warning light indicated an engine problem. None of the crew members was injured, officials said.
The helicopters are attached to Squadron HMX-1 based in Quantico, Virginia, near Washington. The squadron provides helicopters for White House use and support.
The CH-46 was first used in the Vietnam War and is designed to carry troops or up to 5,000 pounds (2,268 kg) of cargo.
The Marine Corps officials said the incidents were under investigation.
